definition:
The *city-block metric*, defined on $\mathbb{R}^n$, is

$$d(a,b) = \sum_{i=1}^n |b_i-a_i|$$

where $a$ and $b$ are vectors in $\mathbb{R}^n$ with
$a=(a_1,\ldots,a_n)$ and $b=(b_1,\ldots,b_n)$.

In two dimensions and with discrete-valued vectors, when we can picture
the set of points in $\mathbb{Z} \times \mathbb{Z}$ as a grid, this is
simply the number of edges between points that must be traversed to get
from $a$ to $b$ within the grid. This is the same problem as getting
from corner $a$ to $b$ in a rectilinear downtown area, hence the name
“city-block metric.”
